Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back badly abraded all over, with only prothorax line surviving; at side, legs reasonably well modelled with undercut triangle, but not with true understanding of structure; underside incised with representation of two animals, arranged one above the other: herbivore lying on its back while lion (?) gnaws at its belly; longitudinally pierced; in bright blue paste, smoothed off by abrasion; much worn surface.
Curator's comments: Lion attacking a prey is a recurrent theme on Egyptian blue scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This specimen belongs to Gorton's type XXXIV, which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, see esp. subtype XXXIV B for this piece). This group varies in style with other animal representations on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids - animals with more elongated bodies, finer incisions - giving the impression that they are of better workmanship (Gorton 1996, 122). This type of representation has a parallel in Archaic Greek gems (e.g. Walters 1926, pl. VIII, no. 450). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Walters, H.E. 1926, Catalogue of the engraved gems and cameos Greek, Etruscan and Roman in the British Museum, London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 139)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.12) (phase 3)
